Negotiating Junior Developer Salaries

Leo


Setup

Intro P: Negotiating is important because reasons.

Due to the huge information asymmetry inherent in negotiating salaries, many negotiations happen in two phases. First, the company pulls some Total Bullshit and hopes you fall for it. Second, the company gives you a genuinely reasonable starting offer, and the negotiation proceeds from there.

Phase One: In Which The Company Tries To Swindle You

If the company opts for Total Bullshit, it usually takes one of the two forms. They ask you to name a number first, hoping you get nervous and low-ball yourself; or they purposely offer you a below-market salary, hoping you get excited and accept anyway. Surviving this phase is completely mechanical! In fact, here's a flow chart:


No matter how much you like or trust the company or your recruiter, run their initial offer through this script. You'll be surprised how often these dirty tactics are used, even by otherwise-great companies. It's just how the proverbial game is played.

Phase Two: In Which You Actually Negotiate

You've passed their naivet√© test. However, whether you're talking with one company or ten, it's worth it to keep going. After all, worst-case you just stay where you are!

From here, if you have multiple offers you should use different tactics based on where each company stands. Divide your offers into tiers based on whatever criteria aside from salary actually matter to you. If you don't know what your criteria are, you should figure that out before continuing. Why does this matter? The less invested you are, the more aggressively you can negotiate.1 In particular: threatening to walk away can be very effective, but you should only do so if you mean it.

  • Tier A: you want to work for THIS company, specifically. This tier should have one company in it, or be empty.
  • Tier B: you would happily work for this company, but it's not your clear favorite. If any Tier B company offered you meaningfully higher compensation than all the others, you'd work for that one.
  • Tier C: you wouldn't realistically work for this company.
  • Finally, let's call your highest offer [Tier]+ and the rest [Tier]-.

Here's how I would finish up. The primary goal here is to just make sure your favorite company matches your best offer; if you can get someone to overshoot, even better.


Once all of your offers reach a steady state, you're all done. Now you just have to decide!

[1] Don't shy away from negotiating aggressively. The person you're negotiating with does this for a living, and I promise that they use more sneaky tricks than you do. But it's not personal on their side, it's just business--and that's how it should be for you. ↩
